options: $T(cu) = cT(u)$ for all scalars $c$ and vectors $u$
$T(u + v) = T(u) + T(v)$ for all vectors $u, v$
Both $T(u + v) = T(u) + T(v)$ and $T(cu) = cT(u)$
questions.explanation: A transformation is linear if it preserves both addition and scalar multiplication: $T(u+v) = T(u)+T(v)$ and $T(cu) = cT(u)$.

questions.prompt: Every linear transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$ can be represented as $T(x) = Ax$ for some matrix $A$.
questions.explanation: True. Every linear transformation between finite-dimensional vector spaces can be represented as matrix multiplication.

questions.prompt: The kernel (null space) of linear transformation $T$ is:
options: The set of all inputs that $T$ maps to zero
The set of all outputs of $T$
The set of all invertible vectors
questions.explanation: ker$(T) = \{x : T(x) = 0\}$, the set of all vectors that map to the zero vector.

questions.prompt: The range of linear transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$ is:
questions.explanation: The range of $T$ is the set of all possible outputs: range$(T) = \{T(x) : x \in \mathbb{R}^n\}$. For $T(x) = Ax$, this is Col$(A)$.

questions.prompt: For any linear transformation $T$, we always have $T(0) = $ ____.
questions.explanation: Linear transformations always map the zero vector to the zero vector: $T(0) = T(0 \cdot v) = 0 \cdot T(v) = 0$.

questions.prompt: A linear transformation $T$ is one-to-one if and only if:
questions.explanation: A linear transformation is one-to-one (injective) if and only if its kernel contains only the zero vector: ker$(T) = \{0\}$.

questions.prompt: A linear transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$ is onto if:
options: Every vector in $\mathbb{R}^m$ is in the range of $T$
questions.explanation: A transformation is onto (surjective) if its range equals the entire codomain: range$(T) = \mathbb{R}^m$.

questions.prompt: If $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^n$ is both one-to-one and onto, then $T$ is invertible.
questions.explanation: True. A linear transformation from $\mathbb{R}^n$ to $\mathbb{R}^n$ that is both one-to-one and onto is an isomorphism and has an inverse.

questions.prompt: The composition of linear transformations $T_1: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$ and $T_2: \mathbb{R}^m \to \mathbb{R}^p$ is:
options: Linear only if both are invertible
questions.explanation: The composition $(T_2 \circ T_1)(x) = T_2(T_1(x))$ is always linear if both $T_1$ and $T_2$ are linear.

questions.prompt: If $T(x) = Ax$ where $A$ is $m \times n$, then $T$ maps $\mathbb{R}^n$ to $\mathbb{R}^{____}$.
questions.explanation: Matrix multiplication $Ax$ where $A$ is $m \times n$ and $x$ is $n \times 1$ produces an $m \times 1$ vector in $\mathbb{R}^m$.

questions.prompt: Two matrices $A$ and $B$ are similar if there exists invertible $P$ such that:
questions.explanation: Matrices $A$ and $B$ are similar if $A = PBP^{-1}$ for some invertible matrix $P$. Similar matrices represent the same transformation in different bases.
Similar matrices have the same eigenvalues, determinant, trace, and characteristic polynomial, but generally different eigenvectors and entries.

questions.prompt: A rotation in $\mathbb{R}^2$ is a linear transformation.
questions.explanation: True. Rotation about the origin is a linear transformation represented by a rotation matrix. It preserves addition and scalar multiplication.

questions.explanation: Translation by a nonzero vector is not linear because it doesn't map the zero vector to zero: $T(0) = b \neq 0$ for translation by $b$.

questions.prompt: The standard matrix of a linear transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$ has columns that are $T(e_1), T(e_2), \ldots, T(e_n)$ where $e_i$ are the ____ vectors.
questions.explanation: The standard matrix $A$ is formed by computing $T$ applied to each standard basis vector: $A = [T(e_1) \; T(e_2) \; \cdots \; T(e_n)]$.
